basicInfo.parentCompany: The Constant Company (privately held; $333M funding in 2024 led by AMD; $3.5B valuation)
basicInfo.notes: Founded in 2014 by David Aninowsky in West Palm Beach, Florida. World's largest privately-held cloud infrastructure company. Operates 32 data center regions across 19 countries on 6 continents. Reached unicorn status in 2024 with $333M funding round led by AMD. Over 80 million cloud servers deployed since founding. Focus on developer-friendly infrastructure with hourly billing.

pricing.moneyBackExclusions: No money-back guarantee; Pay-as-you-go model with hourly billing; Can destroy instances anytime; Unused credit remains in account

serverPerformance.ddosProtectionLevel: Standard DDoS protection included; Advanced mitigation available

policiesOverages.hiddenFeesNotes: Automatic backups cost 20% extra; Snapshots $0.05/GB/month; Bandwidth overage $0.01/GB; Reserved IPs $3/month; No hidden renewal markup; All pricing transparent and pay-as-you-go

business.affiliateCommissionAmount: Up to $100 per referral (customer must be active 30+ days); 30-day cookie; Monthly PayPal payments

editorial.knownIssues: Low Trustpilot rating (2.0/5); No phone or live chat support (ticket only); Strict account verification causing frustration; Reports of account termination without warning; Billing department only available business hours; 20% extra for automatic backups; Snapshots limited to 10 per account; Support response times can be slow; Some users report load balancer outages
editorial.bestFor: Developers wanting affordable cloud compute; Startups needing flexible pay-as-you-go pricing; Users needing many global locations (32 regions); GPU compute and machine learning workloads; API-first infrastructure automation; Users comfortable with self-management; Cryptocurrency payment acceptance
editorial.avoidIf: Need managed WordPress hosting; Want phone or chat support; Beginner requiring hand-holding; Need included email hosting; Want cPanel/Plesk included; Require money-back guarantee; Uncomfortable with unmanaged infrastructure
editorial.competitorComparisonNotes: Cheapest VPS ($2.50) vs DigitalOcean ($4) and Linode ($5); 32 locations (more than DO's 15 or Linode's 11); 100% SLA (vs 99.99% competitors); Lower Trustpilot (2.0) vs DigitalOcean (3.8); No phone support unlike some competitors; More flexible content policies than many; Cryptocurrency payments accepted; G2 rating (4.3) on par with competitors; Hourly billing more granular than monthly-only options

comparisonData.uniqueSellingPoint: Cheapest cloud compute ($2.50/mo) with 100% SLA and 32 global locations
comparisonData.idealCustomerProfile: Developer or startup wanting affordable, flexible cloud infrastructure with global reach

faqContent.faqIsThisHostGood: Vultr is excellent for developers who want affordable, flexible cloud infrastructure. However, it's unmanaged, has limited support options (ticket only), and a low Trustpilot rating due to support issues.
faqContent.faqWhoOwnsThisHost: Vultr is owned by The Constant Company, a privately-held company founded by David Aninowsky in 2014. In 2024, AMD led a $333M investment valuing Vultr at $3.5B.
faqContent.faqHowMuchDoesItCost: Vultr VPS starts at $2.50/month for 512MB RAM. High-performance NVMe instances start at $6/month. All pricing is hourly with no contracts required.
faqContent.faqIsItBeginnerFriendly: No, Vultr is designed for developers and technical users. There's no cPanel, no managed services, and support is ticket-only. Beginners should consider managed hosting alternatives.
faqContent.faqDoesItIncludeEmail: No, Vultr does not include email hosting. You must set up your own mail server or use a third-party email service.
faqContent.faqCanIHostWordPress: Yes, but it's unmanaged. Vultr offers WordPress one-click installs, but you're responsible for security updates, optimization, and maintenance.
faqContent.faqWhatsTheUptime: Vultr guarantees 100% uptime SLA for host nodes and network. If uptime falls below this, you receive account credits up to your monthly cost.
faqContent.faqCanICancelAnytime: Yes, Vultr uses pay-as-you-go hourly billing with no contracts. You can destroy instances anytime and only pay for usage. No money-back guarantee needed.
